question: According to Section 1.4 of Foundations of Data Science with Python, which of these topics are covered in the book?

answers.feedback: Although machine learning is a popular and important data science topic, "Foundations of Data Science with Python" focuses on *Foundations*, meaning more fundamental topics.
"Foundations of Data Science with Python" introduces important data manipulation techniques, such as loading data from files, working with dataframes, and merging data.
Data visualization is one of the first steps of exploratory data analysis and is a major way to communicate results in data science.
Data engineering is concerned with the process of how data is collected, stored, and processed. Most of these topics are outside the scope of this book.
Understanding probability is important in many areas of data science.

question: According to Section 1.5 of "Foundations of Data Science with Python", which of these topics are not covered in the book?

answers.feedback: ML is a popular and important data science topic, but this book focuses on more fundamental topics. See the "Next Steps" section of this website for suggested resources.
Databases are important in many real data science systems, but this topic could not be included in this book. See the "Next Steps" section for suggested resources.
Linear algebra is an important tool for working with data,  but this topic could not be included in this book. See the companion book "Introduction to Linear Algebra for Data Science with Python".
The ethics of data science is an important topic that could not be included in this book. See the "Next Steps" section for some suggested resources.

question: JupyterLab has two main interface modes. Select them below:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. This is not one of the interface modes.
Correct. Use Edit Mode to edit the content of a single cell.
Incorrect. This is a cell type and not a mode of the JuptyerLab interface.
Correct. Use Command mode to select cells and take actions on them, such as moving them or copying and pasting them.
Incorrect. LaTeX is not an interface mode of JupyterLab. It is a way to specify mathematics within Markdown cells.

question: Which of the following are ways to evaluate a cell?

answers.feedback: Correct. This is the most common way to evaluate a cell.
Incorrect. In Edit mode, the Enter key starts a new line. In Command mode, the Enter key switches to Edit mode on the selected cell.

answers.answer: Press the triangular Play button in the tooblar
answers.feedback: Correct.
Incorrect. In Edit mode, Control-M switches to Command mode.

answers.answer: Use Run Selected Cell from the Run menu
answers.feedback: Correct. The Run menu provides many different choices for evaluating cells and shows keyboard shortcuts for those commands.

question: Which of these are used to create formatted text in Jupyter notebooks?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Although Wiki markup or Wiki Text is a way to specify formatted text, it is not the markup language supported in Jupyter notebooks.
Incorrect. SVG is way for specifying scalable vector graphics.
Correct.
Incorrect. Rich text can refer to any markup language or to Rich Text Format, which was created Microsoft. It is not the markup language used in Jupyter notebooks.

question: Which of these are used to typeset mathematics in Jupyter notebooks?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. This is a made-up name.
Incorrect. This is a made-up name.
Incorrect. Although MS Equation is a way to enter equations, it is not the technology used in Jupyter notebooks.
Correct. Jupter notebooks support the mathematical typsetting language from the LaTeX document writing system.

question: Which of these would you use to create a variable called data with value 10 in Python?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. This is how to create that variable in R.
Incorrect. Python does not use the let operator.
Incorrect. Although there is a := operator (called the Walrus operator) that performs assignment, it cannot be used alone like this.
Correct. The variable is created upon assignment using the = operator
Incorrect. The def keyword is to declare a function, not a variable.
Incorrect. This is C/C++ style. Python uses implicit typing and require declaring the type when creating a new variable.

question: Which of the following are used to create functional code blocks in Python?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Curly braces are used to group code in C, C++, and other languages, but not Python
Incorrect.
Incorrect. Blank lines can help distinguish the end of code blocks visually, but do not affect the functional grouping
Correct. The only way to specify functional code blocks in Python is via indentation.

question: Choose all of the following that are used to create comments in Python:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. This is the format of a single-line comment in C.
Correct. A single hash is used to create a single-line comment
Correct. This is used for multi-line comments.
Incorrect. This is a C-style comment.

question: The variable mylist is a Python list. Choose which code snippet will append the item 3 to mylist.

answers.feedback: The Python + operator is not defined for a list and an integer.
Correct. When operating on two lists, the Python + operator performs list concatenation.
Incorrect. In Python, {3} will be a set, and the + operator is not defined for a list and a set.

question: Which of these are valid ways to get access to the functions from the NumPy library?

answers.feedback: Correct. The simplest way to import a library is to just use the import keyword like this.
Correct. This is the typical way to import NumPy. The functions are imported into the np namespace, which is easier to type than numpy.
Incorrect. There is no load keyword in Python. There is a %load magic in JupyterLab/Jupyter Notebook.
Incorrect. Even though the name of the library is NumPy, in Python, it is loaded as numpy (all lowercase).
Incorrect. There is no load keyword in Python. There is a %load magic in JupyterLab/Jupyter Notebook. The library is referred to as numpy (all lowercase) within Python.
Incorrect. This is C/C++ style.
Incorrect. This is how to import a library in R.
